Queer Ecologies


An undergraduate seminar course exploring queer perspectives on familar ecological topics.

title: Aspen Ellis
text:
Welcome!
My name is Aspen Ellis - I’m a seabird conservation ecologist and a Ph.D. candidate and NOAA Dr. Nancy Foster Scholar in the Conservation Action Lab at the University of California, Santa Cruz. My current research focuses on mitigation strategies for the impacts of offshore wind energy development to seabirds. You can download my CV here.



Education
PhD in Ecology & Evolutionary Biology (2021 - present) | University of California, Santa Cruz
BS in Environmental Science (2017) | University of Michigan

title: Aspen Ellis
text: Max: I switched your default git text editor from vim (impossible to use) to nano (merely difficult to use). If it opens (e.g. commit message for a merge), change the text as you want then use ctrl-x to exit. Google the instructions for nano if you get stuck (or call me).

title: Queer Ecologies
text:
Allison Payne and I first designed and taught our course, titled Queer Ecologies, in spring 2023, and re-offered it in Spring 2024. This class was a seminar style undergraduate course designed to expand students’ horizons, uplift queer perspectives in ecology, and build queer community. We’re looking forward to re-offering the class in the future!
Don’t miss checking out our students’ incredible Unessay1 projects here!
